answers.text: according to the frequency of symptoms, forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1), and peak expiratory flow rate

qas.question: When asthma is caused by allergens that is called what?
What  is asthma usually classified based on?
What is a important goal of asthma research?

answers.text: Finding ways to identify subgroups that respond well to different types of treatments

plausible_answers.text: according to the frequency of symptoms, forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1), and peak expiratory flow rate

qas.question: What are two other ways allergen subgroups may be classified?

plausible_answers.text: whether symptoms are precipitated by allergens (atopic) or not (non-atopic)

qas.question: What data is allergen subgroup classification based on?
Is there a method for classifying allergen subgroups beyond the existing system?

plausible_answers.text: Finding ways to identify subgroups that respond well to different types of treatments

qas.question: What is the main goal of allergen subgroup research?

context: Asthma is clinically classified <a0_0><b5_0>according to the frequency of symptoms, forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1), and peak expiratory flow rate<b5_0/><a0_0/>. Asthma may also be classified <a1_0><b6_0>as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic)<b6_0/><a1_0/>, based on <b7_0>whether symptoms are precipitated by allergens (<a2_0>atopic<a2_0/>) or not (non-atopic)<b7_0/>. While asthma is classified based on <a3_0>severity<a3_0/>, at the moment <b8_0>there is no clear method<b8_0/> for classifying different subgroups of asthma beyond this system. <a4_0><b9_0>Finding ways to identify subgroups that respond well to different types of treatments<b9_0/><a4_0/> is a current critical goal of asthma research.
